title: Plea for information on Grenfell Tower fire victims - BBC News
summary: business statement , laying out what 's happening after recess .
peers ask government ministers questions ; including a question on bbc pay .
debates on island communities , euratom and the royal brompton hospital .

documents.title: uk and eu at odds on brexit 'bill '
text: uk and eu at odds on brexit 'bill '

documents.title: goodbye
text: and that 's it for today .
the commons has adjourned - and mps and peers now head off for summer recess .
we bid you goodbye and hope you join us again from tuesday 5 september , when parliament returns .
in the meantime , thank you for joining us .

documents.title: outlining reformsadjournment debate
text: health minister philip dunne is responding to richard drax .
he says he is pleased that mr drax has recognised the excellent care the nhs provides .
he references the commonwealth fund survey which shows that the nhs is the best healthcare provider in the world .
the minister says there will be an increase of £ 8bn in real terms for nhs funding by 2020-21 .
he says the proportion of the pay bill in the nhs towards managers has declined since 2010 from 6.5 % to 5.8 % , he says this money is now being spent on patient-facing services .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: house adjourns
text: the debate comes to an end and the house of lords adjourns .
peers are now off for the summer , and will return on tuesday 5 september .
we wish their lordships a relaxing summer recess
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: tory mp raises nhs concernsadjournment debate
text: after some brief petitions given by peter bone , tom pursglove and fiona bruce , the house moves onto the adjournment debate .
conservative richard drax has tabled this debate on the future of the nhs .
he opens by thanking all those who work for the nhs .
he is keen to point out that this is not a criticism of the government 's policy on the nhs , just `` observations '' he has made `` from the front line '' .
he comments , with concern , on the growing deficits around the country in nhs trusts .
he speaks with concern on mental health services in the nhs , and the internal market system introduced by john major .
`` clearly , the current situation is unsustainable in the long-term , '' he says .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: no final decision has been made - ministerroyal brompton
text: health minister baroness chisholm responds to the debate and tells peers that no final decisions have yet been made and that `` we need to see what the review says '' .
she tells peers that the current review by nhs england is looking at how to take the good service across the country and turn it into `` a truly great service '' for the future .
this is not about closing the royal brompton or stopping it as a provider of congenital heart disease services , she says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: vince cable is new lib dem leader
text: vince cable is new lib dem leader

documents.title: closure 'a tragedy ' say peersroyal brompton hospital debate
text: the chamber is united this afternoon in its condemnation of the proposed closure of the congenital heart disease services at the royal brompton .

peers from across the house have variously described the proposals as `` a very serious loss '' , `` utterly astonishing '' , `` shocking '' , `` insulting '' , `` highly risky '' and `` a tragedy '' .

shadow health spokesperson lord hunt of kings heath joins the discontented voices , and tells the minister that the public are owed a decision by government , but he says he expects that instead of this there will be another review to delay having to make a decision .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'powerful ' speechessummer recess debate
text: michael ellis , deputy leader of the house , is speaking of the many `` powerful '' speeches given during the afternoon 's debate .
he addresses each speech individually and chronologically , responding to concerns raised by mps who have spoken .
he takes the opportunity to thank parliamentary and constituency staff , as well as civil service staff .
the deputy speaker , lindsay hoyle , echoes his remarks on the summer recess .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'not be yaa-boo , but can do'summer recess debate
text: karin smyth , shadow deputy leader of the house , is outlining how brexit and the legislation that follows will be the `` most significant change to legislation our country has seen in the past 40 years '' .
she says mps ' duty in the commons `` should not be yaa-boo , but can do '' .
she wishes everyone in the commons , including the staff , a well-earned rest .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: looking forward to his honeymoon summer recess debate
text: conservative kevin foster hails the government on its decision to move ahead with the school funding formula plans .
he says that schools in his constituency are welcoming the news of guaranteed funding per student .
opening his speech , mr foster jokingly said that the speechwriter for the dup 's jim shannon must be looking forward to recess .
noticing that he is n't in the chamber , mr foster says `` he 's probably busy writing his intervention for the adjournment debate '' .
the mp is widely-known in westminster for his assiduous contributions to debates .

mr foster finishes by saying he is particularly looking forward to the summer recess as plans for his honeymoon were put on hold following his marriage on the 10 june , immediately after the general election .

referring to his wife , mr foster says `` she is certainly looking forward to a few days , because as she pointed out , a trip up here this week to cover my office for a couple of days did n't quite count as the trip away she was looking forward to '' .
the deputy speaker , lindsay hoyle , wishes him a happy honeymoon .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: what is happening at the royal brompton ? royal brompton hospital debate
text: the royal brompton hospital is the largest specialist heart and lung centre in the uk , located in chelsea , in west london .
nhs england has announced plans to decommission congenital heart disease services at the royal brompton .
nhs england is seeking to implement new national standards to centralise services across the country .
in march , over a thousand people took part in a protest against the proposed closures .
labour peer baroness boothroyd is a heart patient at the royal brompton hospital .
in march , baroness boothryod said : `` i have been a patient at the royal years and have had the most superb care . ''
nhs england 's public consultation ended on 17 july and a decision is due to be made shortly .

documents.title: dangerous driving discussedsummer recess debate
text: labour 's liz mcinnes raises the issue of dangerous driver sentencing .
this follows the death of one of her constituents who died after being struck by an uninsured , unlicensed driver in a hire car , she says .
the perpetrator received a six year prison sentence in this case , she says he will probably serve only around three years of that .
she says the government opened a consultation at the end of the last year , which closed in february .
the general election has delayed the progress of this consultation , she adds .
she calls on the justice secretary to get on with the progress of this consultation .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: sir vince becomes new lib dem leaderbbc political correspondent tweets
text: no last minute challengers in the # libdem leadership `` contest '' so sir vince cable is the winner .

documents.title: baroness boothroyd leads last debate of the dayroyal brompton hospital debate
text: the first female speaker of the house of commons , and now crossbench peer , baroness boothroyd is leading the last debate of the day .

the motion for debate is asking the government what clinical evidence it has that the proposed closure of the congenital heart disease services at the royal brompton hospital will lead to improved patient outcomes .
baroness boothroyd accuses the national board of the hospital of being `` high handed , devious , and secretive '' in its dealings with the hospital .
she says that if the congenital heart disease services at the hospital close , the nhs and the country will be poorer .
`` it will be a disaster if it succumbs to the diktat of bureaucracy . ''
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: government 'absolutely committed ' to independent inquiry on blood scandalcontaminated blood inquiry
text: health minister baroness chisholm repeats the answer given to an urgent question earlier in the house of commons on the recently announced contaminated blood inquiry .
labour health spokesperson baroness wheeler asks for assurances that , given the nature of the scandal , the department of health will have no role in how the inquiry is established or conducted .
baroness chisholm says it is normal for the relevant department to sponsor an inquiry - but assures peers that the government is `` absolutely committed '' to an independent inquiry .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: dup stalwart speaks in summer recess debateparliamentary reporters tweet
text: `` people say i always speak in the adjournment debate but there you are , '' says jim shannon in a moment of self-awareness .

documents.title: leaving the eu means leaving euratom - ministereuratom debate
text: lord prior of brampton responds to the debate for the government .
he says it is clear that there must be continuity and no break in the uk 's safeguard regime of nuclear waste .
the government wishes to maintain current safeguard standards , he says - and can do so outside euratom .
`` we are strong supporters of euratom and this is n't going to change , '' he says .

lord prior says the decision to leave the organisation was taken at the time of the triggering of article 50 because the eu and euratom are `` uniquely legally joined '' and that therefore `` leaving one means leaving the other '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: labour say government 'blinded ' by hatred of ecjeuratom debate
text: how many more representations will it take before the government realise they have a made big mistake on euratom , baroness hayter asks .

`` it would be a shame if britain unnecessarily damages itself and one of britain 's enduring and quietly successful entities , '' she says , and accuses the government of allowing what she calls its `` inexplicable hatred '' of the european court of justice to colour `` every aspect of our withdrawal from the eu '' .
this is putting lives , energy and the uk 's safety at risk , she says , and all `` just so we can escape a court '' .
the government must not allow `` some hang up '' about the ecj to blind a sensible way ahead , labour 's brexit spokesperson warns .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: does it matter if the uk leaves euratom ?
text: on 29 march theresa may sent a six-page letter notifying the eu of the uk 's intention to leave .
the article 50 letter contained a clause little discussed at the time - notifying the eu of the uk 's withdrawal from the european atomic energy community , also known as euratom .
but this previously obscure section has now been put under the political spotlight , with some mps , including a number of conservatives , gearing up for a fight on the subject .
one prominent leave campaigner has even said the uk should stay in euratom after brexit .
the bbc 's joey d'urso reports on the issue .

documents.title: what is euratom ?
text: according to the european commission :

euratom aims to pursue nuclear research and training activities with an emphasis on continually improving nuclear safety , security and radiation protection , notably to contribute to the long-term decarbonisation of the energy system in a safe , efficient and secure way .
by contributing to these objectives , the euratom programme will reinforce outcomes under the three priorities of horizon 2020 : excellent science , industrial leadership and societal challenges ''
read more here .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers debate nuclear organisation euratom after brexit
text: the house of lords is holding a debate on euratom .
the debate is designed to discuss ensuring the continued uninterrupted cross-border supply of nuclear materials , including for medical use , post-brexit .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: mp raises parliamentary staff and redundancysummer recess debate
text: the snp 's stewart hosie is raising the problem of parliamentary staff who have moved to london , under the assumption of the last parliament lasting five years , who have now lost their jobs since last month 's general election .
he says the fixed term parliaments act should have provided more certainty for people in public service .
he says that he is not arguing for a return to the old resettlement allowance regime , but thinks that there must be changes made .
he finishes by saying there should be a system allowing for redundancy pay depending on amount of time in office , in cases of people serving less than two years due to a short parliament .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: reading east mp calls for new housing in maiden speechsummer recess debate
text: matt rodda , newly-elected labour mp for reading east , pays tribute to his predecessor , rob wilson , and thanks him for his public service .
he talks about the historic three bs of reading , brewing , biscuit making and bulbs ( horticulture ) .
mr rodda says his constituency `` voted overwhelmingly to remain '' , and says his constituency is opposed to a hard brexit .
he adds that his local residents are concerned about public services , schools , the nhs and the dementia tax .
he says his constituency has a desperate need for new housing .
`` i am honoured to represent my community , '' he finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: grenfell fire update statement repeatgrenfell fire update
text: communities and local government minister lord bourne of aberystwyth is repeating a statement made earlier in the house of commons giving an update on the grenfell tower fire and fire safety .
opposition spokesperson lord kennedy of southwark welcomes the moves by the new leader of kensington and chelsea council to improve trust between residents and the authority .
but he says he is alarmed to learn that 27 samples have not been taken from housing association homes across the country and asks what action is being taken to get these samples .
`` after a month this is totally unacceptable , '' he says .
liberal democrat peer lord shipley says there has been a `` catastrophic failure '' in building control .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: tory mp raises human rightssummer recess debate
text: conservative bob blackman has used his contribution to the debate to raise the subject of human rights in azerbaijan .
he also discusses `` justice for tamils in sri lanka '' , and the `` genocide which took place in iran of political prisoners in 1988 '' .
`` we need to be rolling out our message that human rights are vital , '' he adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

text: what will mps be doing over summer ?

documents.title: isles of scilly ferry 'has always been run commercially ' - ministertrasport for island communities debate
text: transport minister lord callanan says that as an island nation the moving of goods and people by air and sea is `` vital '' to the economic well-being of the country .
speaking of the isles of scilly , he says that ferry services to the islands have always been provided commercially - under both conservative and labour governments .
he says that a new vessel being brought in to serve the isles of scilly seems capable of meeting demand .
the minister tells peers that the government does not see the case for an ongoing subsidy for ferry services but remains committed that services to remote islands continue .
the provision of ferry services is a free market , he reminds peers , and says other operators are free to enter the market if they wish .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: yemen conflict raisedsummer recess debate
text: labour 's keith vaz is using his speech before the summer recess to highlight the issues still facing yemen .

mr vaz , who was himself born in yemen , is raising concerns expressed by the un , medecins sans frontieres and yemen safe passage group for people who have been caught up in the conflict in the country .
he also raises the issues of immigration and visa processing problems currently facing the home office .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peers compare english island ferries with those in scotlandtransport for island communities debate
text: several peers have specifically raised the example of the isles of scilly , describing how a relatively simple task for a mainlander like visiting the hospital or the courts is similar to a `` great expedition '' for an islander .
opposition spokesperson lord rosser highlights a point made by several peers during the debate , which is a comparison with similar air and ferry services to islands in scotland .
he says the ferries in scotland are cheaper , more frequent , and run all through the year - unlike comparable ferries in england .
the market has `` failed to deliver '' a good service to the isles of scilly , he says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: summer recess edges closersummer recess debate
text: mps are taking part in their penultimate business before the summer recess .
as is customary , it 's a general debate , and is on anything mps feel is important to be raised before the summer recess .
this is usually an opportunity for mps to talk about issues they are concerned about and to wish everyone a nice summer .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: query about affordability of essential work
text: clive betts , the chair of the communities and local government committee , says that the secretary of state must accept that work on tower blocks means essential work on other social housing will not happen .
it is clear that it is the legal responsibility of local authorities to make sure their housing is safe , sajid javid says , and no authority has yet come forward to ask for more money .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: questions over local authority and charity donations raisedgrenfell tower fire safety statement
text: the snp 's home affairs spokesperson joanna cherry says the scottish government is looking at the safety of scotland 's high rise towers .
she says many concerns have been raised about the lack of infrastructure and planning in coping with the disaster .
`` was this the failing of one out of touch tory council ? ''
she asks - or is it endemic to other authorities .
she also asks about the money and resources donated to the victims by the public - saying a bbc report claims donations did not receive the victims .
sajid javid replies that with a tragedy on this scale , any local authority would be overwhelmed .
`` despite this , there were things any reasonable person would have expected , '' he says - and there are lessons for authorities across london and the uk .
when it comes to charity funding , the charities commission has been working with the charities to see the maximum benefit from the donations made .
`` any donations that have been made go through that co-ordinated resonse , '' he says .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: any authority 'can approach department for funds'grenfell tower fire safety statement
text: sajid javid says the tests for the cladding that was similar to that on grenfell tower was prioritised .
he says landlords are taking further action to look at cladding that may not be acm cladding , similar to that used at the grenfell tower , too .
and he adds that any local authority that does not have the financial resources can approach his department but no authority has approached the communities department yet .

documents.title: peers debate transport links for island communitiestransport for island communities debate
text: labour peer lord berkeley is now leading the first of this afternoon 's debates on the transport needs of remote island communities in england .

there are a number of communities on islands off the coast of england , particularly on the isle of wight ( iow ) and isles of scilly ( ios ) , who currently only have transport links to the mainland via ferries and/or aircraft .
using these ferry or aircraft services to and from english islands would require greater travel time and expense than the equivalent distance travelled by road .

there are currently no formal island 'frameworks ' or schemes for english islands agreed at government-level , which provide for transport subsidies or extra funding due to any remoteness created by this additional time and expense .
read the full house of lords library briefing for this debate here .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: healey condemns 'no progress ' following grenfellgrenfell tower fire safety statement
text: shadow housing minister john healey responds to sajid javid and says there has been next to no progress .
he said there were two urgent priorities for the government : to help victims and to reassure those who live in tower blocks they were secure .
only 10 families have moved out of emergency homes and hostels ; and mr healey says there are stories of families being offered homes without furniture , or substandard accommodation .
turning to sajid javid 's statement on the testing of cladding - he asks why have only 259 tests been done .
how many of the blocks who have failed tests have had their cladding removed ?
he continues .
and what about financial support to councils and housing associations to help with the cost ?
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: javid updates mps on grenfell tower fire aftermathgrenfell tower fire safety statement
text: communities secretary sajid javid says public servants have been trying to help victims over the past five weeks , since the fire which ripped through the tower block in west london .
`` my aim today is to provide an update before the house rises , '' he says , and says this statement is to let mps know what is happening over the summer .
the death toll remains at 80 vicitms ; with 39 victims formally identified .
he says that there are concerns that the figure looks low and he urges anyone with information about people staying in the tower on the night of the fire to come forward .
he says everyone who lost their home as been made at least one offer of good accommodation - 35 have accepted and 10 have moved in .
some residents have turned down offers , and some are not ready to be engaged and he says the government respects that decision .

turning to the council , he says `` we saw last night the raw anger '' that some feel towards kensington and chelsea council and he says that the independent grenfell recovery taskforce will supervise the council once it takes over administration of the grenfell situation again from the government-appointed emergency `` gold command '' taskforce .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: a warm welcome to the longest-serving peertaking the oath
text: the longest-serving and oldest member of the house of lords , conservative peer lord carrington , took the oath earlier for the new session of parliament at the sprightly age of 98 and was cheered as he shook the lord speaker 's hand .
lord carrington took his seat in the lords in 1945 after serving in world war ii , where he gained a military cross .
he served in churchill 's cabinet in 1951 after the invitation arrived by bicycle .
`` i was at home shooting partridges .
a man on a bicycle came up and said : 'mr churchill wishes to speak to you ' .
i thought he 'd gone mad - why should churchill want to speak to me ?
so i thought i better bicycle back home , so i did and rang up downing street and there he was on the telephone .
`` all he said was : `` 'would you like to join my shoot ? '
i said : 'yes i would ' . ''
lord carrington also served as foreign secretary under margaret thatcher from 1979 until his resignation in 1982 when the argentinians invaded the falkland islands .
the peer also served as secretary general of nato from 1984 to 1988 .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'struggling to get a grip'business statement
text: valerie vaz , shadow leader of the house , accuses the government of `` struggling to get a grip '' .
she says the government does n't want to debate policy issues , but she says the party opposite would rather debate leadership issues .
she asks for a debate on the nhs and on the deficit .
in response , ms leadsom says that the opposition has sought to criticise process , when this `` has just been business as usual in a new parliament '' .
she says she looks forward to the normal committees of the house getting back to work in september .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peers question fox-sky mergerfox-sky merger statement repeat
text: peers respond to a statement repeat on the proposed fox-sky merger , which was made earlier in the house of commons .
labour 's lord stevenson of balmacara says the murdochs have a history of regulatory non-compliance and corporate governance failure that calls their commitment to broadcast standards into question .
liberal democrat lord mcnally says that this amounts to a foreign bid for a british database which should give concern to how it is being handled .
he adds that it would be `` very wrong '' to consider making this decision whilst parliament is in recess .
minister lord keen of elie says that there has been no final decision on any matter and thanks both peers for welcoming culture secretary karen bradley 's efforts to keep parliament informed .
further work will be done on media plurality and broadcasting standards before a decision is made , lord keen says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: eu bill to be debated in septemberbusiness statement
text: the leader of the house , andrea leadsom , outlines business in the commons - the house will return on 5 september .
the main highlight will be the second reading of the european union withdrawal bill , starting on the thursday 7 september ; there will be a second day on monday 11 september .
the first week will include debates on the telecommunications infrastructure bill and approving ways and means resolutions on the finance bill .
there will also be a debate in westminster hall on the 7 september on the transparency of the bbc .

documents.title: the many women in lord ashton 's lifeprivate notice question
text: culture , media and sport minister lord ashton of hyde responds to a question from his conservative colleague lord tebbit about the fact that opposition parties have never elected a female leader , by listing the many women he serves in his private and professional life .

`` i 'm in an interesting position , '' he tells peers , reciting how he `` serves a female prime minister , a female leader of the house , is answering a question from a female leader of the opposition ; my department has a female secretary of state , a female permanent secretary , and a female whip . ''
he goes on to say `` and when i recover i mean when i go home after a very pleasurable day , i go home to a wife and four daughters . ''
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: baroness smith : bbc gender pay criticism 'justified'private notice question
text: culture , media and sport minister lord ashton of hyde says the government does not discuss equal pay with the bbc but it `` does believe in transparency '' and this is why the change in the law was pushed to force the bbc to divulge this information .
baroness smith says that as it is 50 years since the passage of the equal pay act , this is a disappointing answer .
she says that she is proud of the bbc as a `` standard bearer and standard setter '' and says that other media outlets are not as fair and transparent as the bbc .
on the issue of equal pay , however , the criticism `` appears to be justified '' she says .
baroness williams asks why great female broadcasters are paid so much less than their male counterparts .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: question on equal pay at the bbcprivate notice question
text: shadow leader of the house baroness smith of basildon is asking a private notice question on discussions between the government and the bbc regarding equal pay .
yesterday the bbc was compelled to make public information on the pay of stars earning more than £ 150,000 under the terms of its new royal charter .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: call to redouble efforts on health eatingoral questions
text: conservative peer lord robathan asks the government about the slowing of growth of life expectancy .

health minister baroness chisholm of owlpen responds saying that the government follows research on this topic `` with interest '' and that there are a range of factors that contribute to the length of a person 's life .
lord robathan says that in the us life expectancy is falling and `` where america leads we often follow '' .
he asks the government to redouble efforts to promote healthy eating and lifestyle in schools and the nhs to avoid `` innumerable individual tragedies '' and the costs on the nhs .
baroness chisholm says the government takes obesity `` extremely seriously '' and has many initiatives going forward including the new soft drinks levy and on `` harnessing new technology '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: request for culture secretary to appear for questioningfox-sky statement
text: chair of the culture , media and sport committee damian collins asks if karen bradley will be willing to come to answer his committee 's questions once she comes to her decision .
she says she is always happy to be called in front of his committee .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: question on ipp prisonersoral questions
text: crossbencher lord brown of eaton-under-heywood asks about altering the test to be applied by the parole board to the release of those imprisonment for public protection ( ipp ) prisoners who have served years beyond their tariff terms .

justice minister lord keen of elie says that the test used is working and that ipp prisoners are being released in large numbers - with 576 first time releases in 2016 which is the highest number since the ipp sentence was removed .
`` this trend is expected to continue , '' he says .

lord brown of eaton-under-heywood says there are over 3,000 of these prisoners left and whether the minister thinks it is `` fair and appropriate '' for ipp prisoners having to `` prove a negative '' - that they will not re-offend on release .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: sky customer data concerns raisedfox-sky statement
text: lib dem vince cable is asking the culture secretary to not make a decision until the information commissioner provides evidence on the 13 million datasets on sky customers which will be handed over to fox in the event of the merger .
he does n't want this data to be misused for political purposes , a concern raised in the house of lords .
ms bradley says she is aware of these concerns , and under the enterprise act 2002 it is very clear what pieces of evidence she can look at .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'why are we resisting id cards ? ' asks former met commissioneroral questions
text: labour 's lord campbell-savours asks what consideration has been given to the introduction of id cards as a contribution to the maintenance of security in the united kingdom .
home office minister baroness williams of trafford says the government believes id cards would not contribute significantly to the maintenance of security in the country .

lord campbell-savours says that there are 3.2 million eu citizens who are to be given settled status , and who will require a `` national identity card type document '' and says that this opportunity should be used as a test bed for a national roll-out of id cards across the country .
former metropolitan police commissioner lord blair of boughton asks `` why are we resisting something that must be of benefit to the country '' .
baroness williams says that many european countries have id cards and there is no evidence this makes them safer .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'kicking it into the long grass'fox-sky statement
text: the snp 's hannah bardell , their trade and investment spokesperson , says her constituency is affected by the deal as sky is a large employer in her constituency .
she says the snp share the public 's concerns over media plurality .
the decision to possibly announce this over the summer is `` kicking it into the long grass '' , she tells mps , saying the decision is not being open to full scrutiny by the house .
karen bradley rejects the snp claim that she is `` shying away '' from making decisions .
she says the volume of representations means that she has to go through every concern individually .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: what has the culture secretary announced on the fox-sky merger ? fox-sky statement
text: the culture secretary has said she is `` still minded '' to refer rupert murdoch 's 21st century fox takeover of sky to the competition watchdog .
up-dating mps , karen bradley said she had not yet made a final decision , which could take some weeks and a decision might be reached while mps are away from westminster for the summer .
for labour , tom watson said parliament must have the opportunity to `` scrutinise '' the culture secretary 's final decision and ms bradley should not operate to fox 's timetable but that of mps .
mr murdoch already owns 39 % of the satellite broadcaster and has proposed a £ 11.7bn deal to take full control of sky .
an earlier attempt to take over sky was abandoned in the wake of the phone hacking scandal .
author: Simon Jones
Today in Parliament

documents.title: peer 's call to improve transport in north east englandoral questions
text: labour peer baroness quin is asking the government what its priorities for transport investment in the north east of england are over the next two years .

transport minister lord callanan says the government 's priority is a more reliable and less congested transport network that works for users and enhances competitiveness and supports housing growth .
he also says that he expects devolved funds to deliver local plans to help local communities to prosper .
baroness quin notes that she and the minister both stood in gateshead in the 1992 election and that neither of them would have expected to one day be speaking across the red benches .
she asks for the government to bring forward and not delay `` badly needed '' transport infrastructure in the region , for both road and rail .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'government indecision that we welcome'fox-sky statement
text: `` this is one piece of government indecision that we welcome , '' says tom watson , shadow digital , culture , media and sport secretary .
he urges the secretary of state to keep standing firm in the face of pressure from the murdoch family .
he says that there should be no rush to announce the decision over the summer ; this is not to please fox 's shareholders , this should be based on the parliamentary timetable , he adds .
karen bradley says she is acting in a quasi-judicial way , as she is required under the enterprise act 2002 .
she reminds him that under the enterprise act , she has to act without delay , which is why she 's here today , she says , to be as open and transparent as she can be .
she says she hoped to make a firmer decision today , but the `` quantity and volume of representations received '' means that this decision will be slower .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: new scottish tory peer introducedintroduction
text: ian duncan is being introduced as a peer in the house of lords , and is to be a minister at the scotland office .
he will be known as lord duncan of springbank .
lord duncan was formerly an mep and missed out on a seat in the general election by 21 votes when he failed to win election to perth and north perthshire from the snp 's pete wishart .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'still minded'daily mirror 's political reporter tweets
text: new : culture secretary karen bradley `` still minded '' to refer murdoch 's sky takeover to watchdog probe , but not final decision before summer

documents.title: further referral still going ahead on fox-sky mergerfox-sky statement
text: culture secretary karen bradley is making her statement on the proposed merger between fox and sky , and she reminds the house that she was minded to refer the proposal to the competition and markets authority .
she updates the house that she has received letters from fox and sky , which she intends to publish subject to relevant confidentiality agreements .
the consultation closed on friday , and she says she is not yet in a position to announce her decision on further referral .
however , she says she is minded to still refer further .
she says there will be a phase 2 referral on at least one ground , media plurality .
she says she will come to a final decision on referral possibly during the summer recess .
in this case , she adds , she will write to leaders of the parties and speakers of both houses .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: statement on fox and skyfox-sky statement
text: the culture secretary , karen bradley , is giving a statement on the proposed merger between fox and sky .
we 've been covering this story since it started , here 's a bit of background .

documents.title: 'must command the confidence of those affected'contaminated blood urgent question
text: the snp 's martyn day says the inquiry must command the confidence of those affected .
he asks if the minister can confirm when the decision will be made on the department leading the inquiry .
he asks for assurances that the inquiry will have access to everything they need .
jackie doyle-price responds that the department for health will be sponsoring the inquiry , but it will be entirely independent .
she says who is overseeing the inquiry is yet to be determined .
she says the inquiry will be entirely removed from the department once it has been established .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'run roughshod'contaminated blood urgent question
text: sharon hodgson , shadow health secretary welcomes the announcement of the inquiry .
she says that ministers have `` run roughshod '' over the people affected by this in the community , but there are `` deeply held '' sus over the department of health possibly leading this inquiry .
she says that she believes the inquiry should be sponsored by another department , such as the ministry of justice .
responding , the minister says the government is delivering on the promises made last week .
she says that people have waited long enough for answers .
she repeats that no decision has been made on the set up of the inquiry and that the cabinet office is very closely involved on how the government is taking it forward .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: concern over department of health setting up inquirycontaminated blood urgent question
text: labour 's diana johnson , who was granted the urgent question , says that while she is welcoming of the inquiry , she shares the concerns of many people affected by the scandal that the department for health should not set up the inquiry .
`` it is akin , '' she says , `` to asking south yorkshire police to lead an inquiry into the hillsborough disaster . ''
the minister replies that there has been no firm view as to which department will lead the inquiry .
she says that jeremy hunt has made it clear that the government wants to get the inquiry started as soon as possible .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: the scope and range of the inquirycontaminated blood urgent question
text: health minister jackie doyle-price outlines the government 's remit for the forthcoming inquiry which has been announced into contaminated blood .
she says that the government recognises that previous inquiries did not go far enough .
she adds that once the inquiry is established , it will be fully independent .
before it is established , she states , it is important to set the scope and range of the inquiry .
she says it is usual that the relevant government department will set up the inquiry - in this case , the health department .
but in this case , she adds , there have been meetings on this issue , following concerns from those affected by the scandal .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

the main business is three debates on various subjects : including the transport needs of remote island communities in england ; leaving euratom ; and the proposed closure of congenital heart disease services at the royal brompton hospital .

documents.title: cabinet discord ? environment questions
text: labour 's ben bradshaw asks the environment secretary about reported discord in the cabinet , echoed by his former adviser dominic cummings on his twitter feed .

`` is as 'thick as mince , lazy as a toad and as vain as narcissus ' an appropriate description to use of a fellow cabinet member , and if hard brexiteers in our government are falling out in this way , how on earth can the secretary of state expect our european partners to take our negotiations seriously ? ''
he asks .
`` the right honourable gentleman , i 'm sure is aware , that we 're working well together , in government , '' michael gove says , to laughter from the labour benches .
`` i do n't recognise the description he just gave as fitting any member of this house '' , he adds .

she asks .

she adds that one of the report 's authors , professor tim lang , has accused the government of a `` serious policy failure on an unprecedented scale '' .
the minister says the report has not looked at the issues as closely as people in the environment department have .
he says there is nothing in leaving the eu that will affect food security .

she refers to a report published this week saying `` the silence from government on the labour question is astonishing '' .

author: House of Commons

documents.title: good morning
text: it 's the last day of parliament before the summer recess and mps are gearing up for another busy day .
we 'll be crossing to the commons shortly for environment questions , with mps quizzing michael gove and his team of ministers .
thanks for joining us

documents.title: what did david gauke announce on the state pension age ?
text: six million people in their early 40s will have to work a year longer , as a result of a change in the state pension age , the government has announced .
the rise in the pension age to 68 will now happen in 2039 , rather than in 2046 as was originally proposed .
those affected are currently between the ages of 39 and 47 .
the announcement was made by the secretary of state for work and pensions , david gauke today in the commons .
he said the government had decided to accept the recommendations of the cridland report , which proposed the change .
men and women will be affected equally , as the state pension age will have been equalised by then .
the change will affect those born between 6 april 1970 and 5 april 1978 .

documents.title: house of lords adjourns
text: the debate on the financial guidance and claims bill comes to an end for the day and peers adjourn for the evening .
they return tomorrow morning at 11am .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: minister says amendments are 'not appropriate'financial guidance and claims bill
text: the minister rises to say that these amendments `` simply do n't work and are not appropriate '' .
she says that the national financial education strategy will require many organisations working together as this will be more successful than one body working alone .
the strategy will be seen as a collective effort by multiple parties .
baroness buscombe tells peers that she agrees more needs to be done to meet care leavers ' financial needs , and says the new body will look at new initiatives to do this .

she says the body will also look at helping young people with learning difficulties or those leaving youth detention , and that both of these groups - as well as care leavers - are already covered under the existing provisions of the bill .
the amendment would remove the discretion of the body to target those most in need , she says .
after giving assurances to revisit the issues raised in the debate , the amendments are withdrawn .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers debate financial education for young peoplefinancial guidance and claims bill
text: crossbench peer the earl of listowel is now moving an amendment relating to the parts of the bill which seek to introduce a national strategy to improve financial education to children and young people .
his amendment seeks to add care leavers to this list , as he says they are in more danger of falling into financial difficulty when becoming independent due to the lack of support networks .
the earl welcomes government action in this area so far but asks for confirmation from the minister that young people in care will receive financial education and advice before they leave care .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: minister says debt advice is 'crucial'financial guidance and claims bill
text: work and pensions minister baroness buscombe says that the government 's aim for the new single financial guidance body was to give it broad functions .
she adds that the body is able to commission out services where appropriate and that debt advice services will be commissioned .

the provision of debt advice is a core function of the new body , baroness buscombe says , agreeing with other peers in saying problem debt can blight people 's lives and that it is crucial they have access to debt advice .

the minister says she is concerned that the amendments that have been tabled on this part of the bill would restrict advice to only those who are in crisis rather than also to those approaching crisis .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers return to debating debt relief servicesfinancial guidance and claims bill
text: after the short debate peers return to committee stage consideration of the financial guidance and claims bill .

the amendments currently being debated relate to whether sufficient powers and funding are being provided for debt advice services , which are to be free at the point of use , to meet the needs of people in financial crisis in england .
opposition spokesperson lord stevenson of balmacara says he is concerned about the `` scale , scope , and funding '' of the provisions in the bill to deal with this .
he adds that current estimates calculate that there are two million people in england currently in `` financial crisis '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: early action 'absolutely critical ' to positive integration - ministerwelcoming refugees debate
text: home office minister baroness williams of trafford responds to the debate for the government and agrees with peers in saying the time immediately after a refugee is accepted in the uk is `` absolutely critical '' to their integration .
this is `` more crucial than ever '' she says , as the uk has pledged to take in 23,000 refugees on top of existing commitments to current re-settlement regimes .
she says that support for refugees continues for 28 days after a claim is accepted and this is designed to allow refugees to gain employment or claim benefits they may be entitled to .
the minister tells peers that if this time limit proves to not be enough the government will look at it again and will keep parliament updated on any developments .
baroness williams says the home office and the department for work and pensions are working to create a new procedure to help refugees gain employment or apply for benefits .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers call for a minister for refugees to be appointedwelcoming refugees debate
text: a number of peers have spoken in this short debate this evening .

some have spoken of a `` two-tier immigration system '' whereby refugees who arrive in the uk through re-settlement programmes are given support and housing , and asylum seekers are given much less in comparison .

other peers have called for a dedicated minister for refugees to be appointed , with some arguing that this minister should be moved out of the home office to remove the association with law enforcement .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: debate on welcoming refugeeswelcoming refugees debate
text: the bishop of durham is leading the dinner break debate this evening on the all party parliamentary group on refugees ' report , refugees welcome ?
the experience of new refugees in the uk .
the bishop says that despite the desire of many in the uk to welcome refugees , `` our systems often leave them bereft and destitute '' .
he says that although defining successful integration is `` incredibly complex '' he thinks it is when someone wants to give to , and be involved in , the community they have joined .

he says that a specific national refugee integration strategy `` makes sense '' and should be led and organised around a vision for `` thriving individuals and communities '' - saying that this is currently organised by the `` quirks of the dwp and short term cost cutting '' .
`` refugees deserve better . ''
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: peers debate 'breathing space scheme ' for those in debtfinancial guidance and claims bill
text: peers from across the chamber are speaking in favour of this group of amendments that would introduce financial support for indebted people to allow a `` breathing space '' to seek financial advice .

crossbencher baroness meacher , the bishop of newcastle , and liberal democrat peer lord kirkwood have all spoken about the misery caused by problem debt - to both the individual and to families , particularly children .
minister baroness buscombe says that the government supports a coordinated national strategy to help people manage debt and provide financial education to young people .
she says that this is not the right piece of legislation in which to pursue this issue however , and does not specify a future bill which would be suitable when pressed by peers .
`` we are really wanting to take this forward with care '' she says , and the government is `` very committed '' to it in principal .
the amendments are withdrawn .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: and that 's it
text: the lighting is restored just in time , as the house adjourns .
the commons will return tomorrow morning at 9:30am .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: do not adjust your tv set adjournment debate
text: the house of commons did just temporarily lose their lighting .
`` the situation , lighting wise , is slightly throwing me off '' says margot james , as the lights in the house of commons cut out .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: an 'extremely competitive market'adjournment debate
text: minister margot james from the business , energy and industrial strategy department is speaking on behalf of the government .
she says her thoughts are with those who have lost their jobs in this decision by tesco .
she reassures the house that the government will support all of those affected as quickly as possible through jobcentre plus .
following an intervention from labour 's ruth george , the minister accepts that 45 days is a `` short '' amount of time for people to find a new job .
she says that retail is an `` extremely competitive market at the moment '' , companies will need to expand , merge , `` but also contract '' in response to what happens in the market .
ms james adds that the department of work and pensions and jobcentre plus have already been in contact with tesco following the decision .
the south east wales district jobcentre plus will deploy their redundancy response action plan , she says , `` this will deliver a bespoke package of support '' , she adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: tesco job losses in the spotlightadjournment debate
text: and now we 're on to the final part of today 's business in the commons .
labour 's anna mcmorrin who represents cardiff north , has tabled an adjournment debate on job losses at tesco .
our colleagues in wales have been reporting on this , you can see a bit of background below
tesco announced 1,100 job losses in its cardiff office on the 21 june .
ms mcmorrin says a pa system was brought into the office on the morning of the announcement of the job losses .
the decision was announced and there was no opportunity for questions , she says .
some employees only heard of the closure on social media , she adds , following an intervention from labour 's wayne david .
she agrees with her labour colleague ms stevens of cardiff central that of ceo dave lewis ' £ 4.15m pay this year , some of it could have been used to protect jobs .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'maximising political pressure'exiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: sir alan duncan , foreign office minister , is summing up for the government .
he says the government intends to continue working closely with allies , to counter threats of terrorism , conflict and proliferation of nuclear weapons .
he adds that sanctions are an important part of this broad and internationally co-ordinated approach .
most sanctions come from the un security council , or the eu , he says .
both of these sanctions are brought into effect in the uk under the european communities act 1972 .
he says he wants to reassure members that the government remains committed to the principals of careful targeting , and maximising political pressure while minimising potential consequences .
the minister adds that the government intends to remain `` aligned and in harmony '' with the existing eu sanctions .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: mps must 'take hold ' of brexit process - labourexiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: jenny chapman , shadow exiting the eu minister , is now summing up for labour .
she calls the debate this afternoon useful and helpful .
she says it `` falls to mps to take tight hold of this process '' and not allow government to take decisions , grab powers or devise processes that `` exclude parliament '' , she adds .
she says the eu withdrawal bill undermines parliamentary scrutiny .
`` labour agrees that international sanctions is a vital issue that must be resolved before we leave the eu '' , she says , `` we will not seek to obstruct the forthcoming legislation needlessly '' .
`` britain 's national security is enhanced by working with our european allies , and there 's no reason why this ca n't continue after brexit '' , she tells mps .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: new finance body will be free at the point of usefinancial guidance and claims bill
text: a number of peers have raised concerns that the new single financial guidance body created by the bill is free at the point of use and that advice offered by the new agency is independent and impartial .
minister baroness buscombe says that the government `` absolutely agrees '' that any help offered by the new body should be free at the point of use .
`` we would not wish members of the public be unable to access help because of cost , '' she says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: britain is no longer a colonial empire , says snp mpexiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: the snp 's europe spokesperson , peter grant , is speaking .
he raises concerns over the us president and his recent secret meeting with vladimir putin .
he asks how , if the us breaks sanctions with russia , the uk would respond to such a situation .
he states that britain is no longer a colonial empire , the british empire `` does not extend any further than the british isles '' he says .

mr grant warns there 's a `` real danger '' that in order to try and prove some `` political machismo '' , the uk could end up looking like a laughing stock , although , he says , `` i think it 's a little too late for that '' .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: 'reluctant leaver ' calls brexit 'right choice'exiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: andrew lewer , newly-elected conservative mp for northampton south , pays tribute to the former mp for his constituency , david mackintosh .
he also references other mps who have served the area .
northampton is one of the fastest growing towns in the country , he says , and it has been for decades .
this places pressures on public services and for housing .
he pledges to work with the member for northampton north , michael ellis , on these issues .
he says he is the only person ever to have served as a council leader , mep and mp .
as an mep he specialised in culture , media and education , he adds .
he says he was a `` reluctant leaver '' , but he still believes it was the right choice for the uk .
he adds that the complexity of the issues facing the uk underlines how much sovereignty the uk had lost .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: unexpected visitorconservative mp tweets
text: i have just seen a seal swimming up the thames past # parliament .

documents.title: snp mp warns against following trump 's agenda on sanctionsexiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: snp mp hannah bardell says the uk 's international reputation is on the line when it comes to brexit .

`` there is a risk that as a result of leaving the eu , the uk will be marginalised and diminished on the international stage , '' she says - and that means a reduction of the uk 's ability to impose meaningful sanctions .
working with the eu gives the uk a broader range of tools , she says , and giving up a seat will see the uk losing the ability to apply sanctions with the same `` breadth and weight '' .

she urges the government not to diverge from the eu path when it comes to applying sanctions ; particularly to resist the idea of converging with us and particularly donald trump 's interests , when it comes to russia in particular .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: nigerian childhood 'led new mp to be conservative'exiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: kemi badenoch , newly-elected mp for saffron walden says that , like the deputy speaker eleanor laing , she is proud to be an essex girl .
`` after seven years of conservative-led government , unemployment is at an all time low of 0.7 % , '' she says of her constituency .

she tells mps that she was born in wimbledon but grew up in nigeria , and she saw how the state electricity and water companies failed people in supplying their utilities , and this is one of the reasons why she is a conservative .
she corrects the often misinterpreted quote from john bright , the reformer , on the house of commons `` the mother of all parliaments '' .
she says that what he actually said was `` this country is the mother of all parliaments '' .
she says the british parliament has always adjusted , and that is why it leads in the world , it has always taken its lead from the people that it serves .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: chaos and confusion for sanctions regime - goodmanexiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: labour 's helen goodman speaks from the dispatch - although , currently , she does not hold a formal frontbench position .
she says sanctions `` are obviously an extremely important policy lever '' ; and demands to know about a proposed bill , following the closure of the consultation on future foreign policy sanctions .
alan duncan , foreign office minister , intervenes to tell ms goodman that the general election delayed the publication of this .
she says this still remains another example of chaos and confusion from the government in the whole brexit process .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: uk 'will need new laws'exiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: robin walker echoes the prime minister when he says the government is working to create a truly global britain .

the uk is under threat from states which act in contravention of international law , from individuals preaching hate , to corrupt companies , and the uk needs as many tools as available to counter these threats , he adds .
the uk currently implements around 34 sanctions regimes , around half of these come from the european union , he says .
the minister adds that the uk must retain the ability to impose , retain and update sanctions after exiting the eu , he states .
he says that when the uk leaves the eu in march 2019 , the government will need law in place to impose sanctions .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: on to the next debate exiting the eu and sanctions general debate
text: deputy speaker eleanor laing thanks members for holding a debate which has come in under time without a formal time limit .
she also thanks the new members for their `` excellent '' maiden speeches .
robin walker , exiting the eu minister , is now opening the general debate on exiting the eu and sanctions .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: new hartlepool mp promises to fight for constituentsdebate on tuition fees
text: labour 's new mp mike hill says he was the first person in his family on a `` wing and prayer '' he knows how difficult it is for students facing debt as a result of tuition fees .

he pays tribute to previous hartlepool mps in his maiden speech , including peter mandelson , who he thanks for helping to regenerate the town - and , he jokes , for flying the flag for that little known northern delicacy guacamole .
and he remembers his predecessor iain wright , and his work as chair of the business committee .
as usual , he pays tribute to his constituents and their humour , remembering their voting for a monkey mascot as mayor .
he says he is in the commons to support public services and the nhs .
fighting the austerity agenda is his priority , he says , as well as working for an improvement in mental health services .
he references his union roots and the co-operative movement .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: new manchester gorton mp pays tribute to terror victimsdebate on tuition fees
text: another new maiden speech - this time it 's the turn of labour 's new mp for manchester gorton , afzal khan .
he says many young people are facing the increased burden of tuition fees .
he talks about may 's terror attack in manchester , paying tribute to the solidarity and compassion with which people in manchester responded .
he says he ca n't think of a more powerful message to the terrorists and the bigots , that he is now the first bme and muslim mp representing manchester .
he pays tribute to the late sir gerald kaufman , who died earlier this year .
he says he will try and continue his work in the house , and knows he will be a hard act to follow .
challenges facing his constituency include less police on the streets and cuts to council budgets , he says .
he was adopted by a family in manchester after being born in pakistan into poverty .
he left school with no qualifications , went to work as a labourer in a cotton mill , then a bus driver and later a police officer .
while supporting his wife and young children , he attended night school in law , and eventually became a partner in the law firm which subsequently employed him , he tells mps .
he also served as lord mayor of manchester and has been an mep .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: committee stage in the lordsfinancial guidance and claims bill
text: peers now turn to their bread and butter - line by line scrutiny of legislation in one of the first committee stage sessions of a bill in this new parliament .
the bill would merge three existing , government-sponsored , financial and pension guidance services : the money advice service , the pensions advisory service and pension wise .
in so do doing , it would create a new single financial guidance body ( sfgb ) .
the bill would also make changes to the regulation of claims management companies ( cmcs ) .
cmcs provide advice and services to assist people in making compensation claims in various sectors , such as personal injury and financial products .
regulatory responsibility for cmcs would transfer from the ministry of justice to the financial conduct authority ( fca ) .
read the full house of lords library briefing on the bill here .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: 'austerity is lifeless ' - new labour mpdebate on tuition fees
text: james frith , labour 's newly-elected mp for bury north , gives his maiden speech , speaking about his life and his constituency .
he talks about his daughter jemima , who , after he explained to her what an mp does - try to help people , listen to people - she described him `` as my mp already '' .
this draws a chorus of `` ahh '' from the labour benches .
he pays tribute to david nuttall , the previous bury north mp , who he calls an `` affable man '' .
he describes recent history as `` seven years of bad luck for bury '' .
`` for bury north , i 'm here to help determine what comes next . ''
`` austerity is not living within our means , austerity is lifeless , '' he adds .
he closes his speech in calling for more grace in discussion of brexit , less of the bombastic approach .
he says people did not vote to make themselves poorer .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: lord dubs asks if government will accept more childrenunaccompanied child refugees statement
text: labour peer lord dubs , who led the successful campaign in parliament to push the government to accept unaccompanied child refugees - and was himself a child refugee from the nazis , asks for a `` simple answer to a simple question '' .
`` once we have reached 480 is that the end of it or will the government respond to local authorities who say they are willing to take more ? ''
baroness williams replies saying that the figure of 480 is a `` specified number '' and is the one which has been agreed by government .
she tells peers that local authorities do not just take child refugees from the dubs scheme and only have a limited capacity .
`` we are always wiling to listen to local authorities , '' she says , but warns that government have stated the specified number and are bound by local capacity .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: situation for child refugees 'a catastrophe'unaccompanied child refugees statement
text: crossbencher baroness butler-sloss says there has been `` no effort whatsoever '' to identify 'dubs children ' anywhere in europe and describes some of the circumstances unaccompanied children face .
`` it is a catastrophe for these children and nothing seems to be done , '' she says .

baroness williams says the responsibility for the children lies with the country in which they are residing , but tells the baroness that the uk is working closely with the relevant european countries .
the safest way for eligible children to make it to the uk is to claim asylum in france , the minister says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: streeting : graduates in the uk have the highest levels of debtdebate on tuition fees
text: labour 's wes streeting says that the uk now has the highest levels of student debt in the world .
he says that students from the poorest backgrounds now graduate with the highest levels of debt .
he speaks about how despite growing up in poverty , he still had opportunities available to him .
the policies of successive conservative governments have led to `` such a state where we are disrupting children 's education '' , he says .

although they may be the largest party , there is a reason they did n't win a majority at this general election , because of the deep detachment that they have from every day people in this country , he finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: statement on 'dubs amendment ' to immigration act 2016unaccompanied child refugees statement
text: home office minister baroness williams of trafford repeats the answer given to an urgent question earlier in the house of commons on section 67 of the immigration act 2016 .

section 67 of the immigration act 2016 came from what was widely known at the `` dubs amendment '' under which the uk pledged to take in an unspecified number of unaccompanied refugee children from europe .
the eponymous dubs amendment to the 2016 immigration bill required the government to bring child refugees to the uk .
lord dubs had called for 3,000 unaccompanied refugee children to be brought to the uk .
the government suffered a significant defeat in the house of lords on the amendment during the passage of the bill .
in february , the government announced that it would close the dubs scheme after accepting 350 refugees .
the government said 200 children had already arrived and 150 more would follow by the end of march 2017 .
today 's statement gives a figure of 480 children , although baroness williams insists the scheme is not closed and that there are still places available .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: current prisons situation is 'unacceptable ' - ministersafety in prisons statement
text: peers now respond to the repeat of an answer given to an urgent question in the house of commons this afternoon on safety in prisons and youth custody centres .

labour frontbencher lord beecham says there has been a `` staggering '' decline in safety in young offenders institutes , quoting a report by the chief inspector of prisons in saying that the situation is `` dangerous , counter-productive and will end in tragedy if action is not taken '' .
lord beecham says the current state of prisons is `` scandalous '' .
justice minister lord keen of elie says that it is not the case that all centres have failed safety inspections , but admits the current situation is `` unacceptable and must be addressed '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: new mp recounts husband 's suicidedebate on tuition fees
text: liz twist , newly-elected labour mp for blaydon , starts her maiden speech thanking those who have voted for her , and pays tribute to her predecessor , dave anderson .
she says she knows how important the tuition fees issue is for her local area , as it became a big talking point during her election campaign .

she talks about the strong mining links in blaydon and the local area ; then tells mps how her former husband took his own life , and how suicide is more prevalent among people with unemployment , job uncertainty and poverty .

an employee on a zero hours contract is someone 's parent or child , a person about to lose their job may be a sibling or a friend , and each one will leave others disadvantaged too , if they take their own life , she finishes .
author: House of Commons
Parliament
