daily politics getting desperate .

documents.title: education committee chair raises disadvantaged student numbersdebate on tuition fees
text: education committee chair robert halfon says the fees system must strike a balance between burdening students and the taxpayer .
interest rates charged should be fair for students , he adds .

he explains how the committee has heard that while the numbers of disadvantaged students attending university has increased , this has not happened at the top tier universities , where disadvantaged student numbers have fallen .
value for money is another issue he mentions .
he says if people are paying £ 9,000 plus , but coming out and getting a good job , then `` job done '' .
if they are not , he adds , then the reasons why need to be asked .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: minister : opposition 'failing to appreciate the situation'pensions statement
text: work and pensions minister baroness buscombe responds that it is `` really important to have a seriously responsible '' approach to the problems faced in the area of pensions .
she says that the opposition 's wish to fix the pension age at 66 demonstrates a failure to appreciate the situation .
this policy , she says , would add £ 250 billion to national debt spending by 2040 , which is £ 20 billion a year `` borne by future generations '' .
baroness buscombe says it is `` hugely important '' to take these steps now by acting `` responsibly and with care '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: opposition parties respond to pensions statementpensions statement
text: labour frontbencher lord mckenzie of luton now responds to the statement repeat on the government 's plan to increase the state pension age to 68 between 2037 and 2039 , rather than from 2044 as was originally proposed .

lord mckenzie says the government 's response to this is `` disappointing '' , and goes on to say that `` astonishingly '' there is nothing in the government 's announcement that acknowledges inequality in income or life expectancy .
there are `` huge variations '' in life expectancy across the country , he says .
liberal democrat pensions spokesperson lord kirkwood of kirkhope urges the government to mitigate some of the transitional problems by using some of the savings from the policy .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: hereditary peer by-election result announced
text: before the statements begin , a clerk officially announces lord vaux of harrowden as the winner of a hereditary peer by-election held following the recent retirement of lord walpole .
27 crossbench peers voted in the by-election , choosing between 10 candidates .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: labour mps 'pulled up ladder behind them'debate on tuition fees
text: from the snp benches , marion fellows says that snp mps will seek to oppose any bill which would increase fees for students .
she says she has always remained `` incensed '' at the idea that students should pay fees .
she says that she was always disappointed in university-educated labour mps for `` pulling up the ladder behind them '' by introducing fees .
she adds that everyone benefits from people going to university due to a higher tax take and from having university-educated teachers , doctors and lawyers .
`` sometimes even mps '' , she adds .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: peer questions timing of rates relief paymentsoral questions
text: conservative peer lord naseby asks what action is being taken to ensure that businesses eligible for support from the business rates hardship fund receive it without delay .
he says current problems are having a `` huge effect '' on cash flow and asks for the government to make sure this is solved in the next month .

communities and local government minister lord bourne of aberystwyth responds that allocations of funds have been made to local councils and the government `` looks to them '' to implement the necessary functions .
lord bourne says the government will consider further action if councils do not comply with its instructions .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: industrial strategy 'ambitious and enduring'oral questions
text: liberal democrat lord fox asks what conclusions have been drawn from the consultation on the introduction of a new industrial strategy .

business , energy and industrial strategy minister lord prior of brampton replies that the government has an `` ambitious and enduring '' industrial strategy that sets a clear long-term vision and works `` for all parts of the country '' .
labour peer lord west of spithead - a former first sea lord - uses the question to raise a favourite topic of his which is to encourage ministers to build more ships for the royal navy .

a `` key plank '' of any industrial strategy is a ship building strategy , he says - which prompts ironic cheers from fellow peers who are used to his tenacity in bringing this topic up at every possible opportunity .
he says there are too few escort ships , and that it is `` a national disgrace '' .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: labour mp : 45 % of student loans not repaiddebate on tuition fees
text: labour 's gareth snell intervenes on the minister , saying that 45 % of all student loans taken out are never repaid .
he says the 30-year rule means 70 % of students have an outstanding loan .
he asks mr johnson if he has done the figures to see if the money the government has to pay now on loans could instead be used to reduce the upfront costs of going to university .
the universities minister says the government contribution towards the loan book is a conscious decision to support everyone going to university and towards the skills base of the country .
he adds that the government wants people to pursue worthwhile , socially valuable jobs which may not necessarily lead to high earnings , such as social work .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: uk troops in east africa doing 'incredible work ' - ministeroral questions
text: crossbench peer the earl of sandwich asks the government what action it is taking over the ongoing refugee crisis and acute food emergency in east africa .

international development minister lord bates responds saying the uk provides life saving support across the region , including food aid to 3.3 million people and 2.4 million with water and sanitation .
the uk is leading a new approach , he says , which includes long-term investment in jobs and education .
the earl says that this is one of the most dangerous places in africa , and asks the minister about how the government provides security for aid workers .
there are 400 british troops there doing `` incredible work '' lord bates says .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: the crown dependencies and brexitoral questions
text: liberal democrat peer lord beith asks what contact the government has had with the crown dependencies about brexit negotiations .

exiting the eu minister baroness goldie says the relevant minister has spoken with the chief ministers in jersey , gurnsey , and the isle of man as part of `` regular '' talks , and the government is `` absolutely committed '' to engaging with them .
lord beith says that these discussions have yet to be tested `` under the pressure of negotiations , '' and that access to the single market is important to these places .
leaving the eu with no deal would be `` disastrous for the uk and bad for the crown dependencies '' , he adds .
author: House of Lords
Parliament

documents.title: debate is 'sham exercise'debate on tuition fees
text: jo johnson , the universities minister , says the debate is a sham exercise , `` more cynical politics '' , like the labour broken promise that it would `` write off historic student loan debts '' .
this is not new terrain , he says - in the june 2015 budget , it was announced that tuition fees would rise and it was set out in july 2016 .
tuition fees were debated during he bill , with numerous votes ; and the resolution were not `` proposed '' but have been in force for six months .
he goes on to attack labour policy on tuition fees .
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: what about labour 's promises on tuition fees ? debate on tuition fees
text: in an intervention , conservative james cartlidge asked ms rayner if it was labour 's policy to pay off all outstanding student debt .
ms rayner said the conservatives were misrepresenting the party 's policies .
`` we have never said that we would simply write off all existing debt , '' she says .
`` they refer to comments made by ( mr corbyn ) and i would remind them that he said we would look at steps to reduce or eliminate the debt burden .
`` perhaps this confused members opposite , that is not something their frontbench has done for seven years .

`` for instance , we would look again at the repayment threshold for student debts , which they have frozen at £ 21,000 we would look at the interest rates on debt , which they allowed to reach an extortionate , unacceptable 6.1 % in the year to come .
`` and i 've said once , and i will say it again , we have no plans to write off existing student debt and we never promised to do so . ''
author: House of Commons
Parliament

documents.title: debt levels 'unsustainable ' - labourdebate on tuition fees
text: leaving the situation unclear is unhelpful , angela rayner says .
the current government 's plans are part of a pattern of behaviour , she says - saying tuition fees have tripled and maintenance grants have been abolished .
students are telling us debt levels at the moment are unsustainable , she says .
